article.title: The weighted poset metrics and directed graph metrics

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the P-weight of element 2 in the induced weighted poset P?
Which element in the induced weighted poset P has a P-weight of 2?
What does Figure 3 illustrate regarding the relationship between a digraph G and its induced weighted poset P?
choices: G is always equal to Gπ.
G is not generally equal to Gπ.
P is always smaller in size than G.
There's no relationship between G and Gπ.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which type of metric is obtained when a digraph has no cycles in the "diagram of metrics"?
How many elements in the weighted poset P have a Pπ-weight of one?
What is the structure vector (Ω¹(1), Ω²(1), Ω(2)) of the weighted poset structures shown in Figure 6?
What is the common characteristic of the weighted poset structures P1, P2, P3, and P4 shown in Figure 7?
choices: They all admit H3 to be a 2-perfect code.
They all have the structure vector (3, 1, 4).
They all have the same labeling for their elements.
They all have the same number of maximal elements.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of structures are depicted in Figure 8?
What is the relationship between the digraphs in Figure 9 and the weighted posets in Figure 6?
choices: The digraphs correspond to the weighted posets.
The digraphs are subgraphs of the weighted posets.
The weighted posets are induced by the digraphs.

multiple_choice_question.text: How many directed cycles are present in the digraph G1 shown in Figure 10?
What differentiates the digraphs in Figure 11 from the digraph G1 in Figure 10?
choices: The connections between elements in Γ²(β), Γ²(γ), and Γ²(δ).
The number of elements in Γ³.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of structures are shown in Figure 12?
What is the Pπ-weight of element 5 in the weighted poset shown in Figure 13?
